page.title: 02THE GLENLIVET DISTILLERY
page.content: George Smith first began distilling in 1822 and took out the first Customs and Excise licence in 1824 thus creating uproar in the illicit whisky trade. Distilling still continues in the traditional way but now, with all the modern machinery, fewer men are required in the different departments - gas fired stills now take the place of coal, and the barley is bought in already malted instead of being done at the distillery with peat cut from the famous Faemusach Moss. Old timers claim it was this peat which gave 'The Glenlivet' its special flavour. About 75% of whisky produced is sold to blenders but 'The Glenlivet' is still bottled at 12 year old for home and export. There are 20 duty free warehouses for storing whisky until it is required for blending or bottling.
